pageTitle: WRC champ Sebastien Loeb finally decides to hang up his hat: Year in Review 2012 | Autoweek
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {4870=World Rally Championship fans this year witnessed the end of an era. Sébastien Loeb -- following a decade of domination during which he won nine world titles (10, if you count his 2001 Junior WRC title) -- decided finally to walk away from full-time rallying., 5961=December 26, 2012, 5383=Sebastien Loeb won his ninth world title in 2012. He also decided to take a break from full-time rallying. Photo by LAT PHOTOGRAPHIC, 3842=However, at the start of the season, everything seemed like business as usual, with yet another Loeb victory in Monte Carlo. After that, the year didn’t quite go according to plan for him, or at least not completely. In Sweden, he could only manage sixth as Ford’s Jari-Matti Latvala won. Loeb won the next round, which was held in Mexico, but then came the low point in Portugal: He crashed on the first day after mishearing a pace note. On the other hand, his new Citroën teammate, Mikko Hirvonen, went on to win the event, and the Finn would have taken the championship lead, too. But surprisingly, post-race inspectors deemed Hirvonen’s car illegal on two counts—a non-homologated clutch and an oversize turbo part, which Citroën insisted provided absolutely zero performance gains—and disqualified him. The result was the first win for a privateer entry, Mads Østberg, since 1993, while Hirvonen would have to wait until Rally Sardinia at the end of the year for his first Citroën win.}
textBeforeTable: 2015 World Rally Championship Shedule --> Comments See MoreWorld Rally Championship By Anthony Peacock After Portugal, though, the script began to get back on track for Loeb. The only rallies he didn’t win during the rest of the season were Great Britain (won by Latvala) and Italy (Hirvonen), and he clinched the title on home territory in France, shortly after he announced his decision to scale back his rally activity to just a handful of events next year.
